"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Enable audit Logs"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": and deploy your applicat ions through the managed Kubernetes API server. To help troubleshoot your application and services
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": you may need to view the logs generated by these control plane components. To help collect and review data from multiple sources
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": Azure Monitor logs provides a query language and analytics engine that provides insights to your environment. A workspace is used to collate and analyze the data

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the kubeconfig file permissions are set to 644 or more restrictive"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "If kubelet is running
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": and if it is configured by a kubeconfig file
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": ensure that the proxy kubeconfig file has permissions of 644 or more restrictive."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "The kubelet kubeconfig file controls various parameters of the kubelet service in the worker node. You should restrict its file permissions to maintain the integrity of the file. The file should be writable by only the administrators on the system. It is possible to run kubelet with the kubeconfig parameters configured as a Kubernetes ConfigMap instead of a file. In this case
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": there is no proxy kubeconfig file."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the kubelet kubeconfig file ownership is set to root:root"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "If kubelet is running
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": ensure that the file ownership of its kubeconfig file is set to root:root ."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "The kubeconfig file for kubelet controls various parameters for the kubelet service in the worker node. You should set its file ownership to maintain the integrity of the file. The file should be owned by root:root ."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "None"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the azure.json file has permissions set to 644 or more restrictive"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The azure.json file in an Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) cluster is a configuration file used by the Kubernetes cloud provider integration for Azure. This file contains essential details that allow the Kubernetes cluster to interact with Azure resources effectively. It' s part of the Azure Cloud Provider configuration
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": enabling Kubernetes components to communicate with Azure services for features like load balancers
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": storage
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": and networking. Ensure the file has permissions of 644 or more restrictive."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "The azure.json file in AKS structure typically includes: - Tenant ID: The Azure Tenant ID where the AKS cluster resides. - Subscription ID: The Azure Subscription ID used for billing and resource management. - AAD Client ID: The Azure Active Directory (AAD) application client ID used by the Kubernetes cloud provider to interact with Azure resources. - AAD Client Secret: The secret for the AAD application. - Resource Group: The name of the resource group where the AKS cluster resources are located. - Location: The Azure region where the AKS cluster is deployed. - VM Type: Specifies the type of VMs used by the cluster (e.g.
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": standard VMs or Virtual Machine Scale Sets). - Subnet Name
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": and Vnet Resource Group: Networking details for the cluster. - Route Table Name: The name of the route table for the cluster. - Storage Account Type: The default type of storage account to use for Kubernetes persistent volumes."

This file contains essential details that allow the Kubernetes cluster to interact with Azure resources ef fectively. It's part of the Azure Cloud Provider configuration

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--anonymous-auth argument is set to false"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Disable anonymous requests to the Kubelet server."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "When enabled
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": requests that are not rejected by other configured authentication methods are treated as anonymous requests. These requests are then served by the Kubelet server. You should rely on authentication to authorize access and disallow anonymous re quests."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Anonymous requests will be rejected."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--authorization-mode argument is not set to AlwaysAllow"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not allow all requests. Enable explicit authorization."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Kubelets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": by default
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": allow all authenticated requests (even anonymous ones) without needing explicit authorization checks from the apiserver. You should restrict this behavior and only allow explicitly authorized requests."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--client-ca-file argument is set as appropriate"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Enable Kubelet authentication using certificates."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "The connections from the apiserver to the kubelet are used for fetching logs for pods
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": attaching (through kubectl) to running pods
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": and using the kubelet's port-forwarding functionality. These connections terminate at the kubelet's HTTPS endpoint. By default
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": the apiserver does not verify the kubelet's s erving certificate
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": which makes the connection subject to man-in-the-middle attacks
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": and unsafe to run over untrusted and/or public networks. Enabling Kubelet certificate authentication ensures that the apiserver could authenticate the Kubelet before submi tting any requests."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": "You require TLS to be configured on apiserver as well as kubelets."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--read-only-port is secured"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Disable the read-only port."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "The Kubelet process provides a read-only API in addition to the main Kubelet API. Unauthenticated access is provided to this read-only API which could possibly retrieve potentially sensitive information about the cluster."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Removal of the read-only port will require that any service which made use of it will need to be re-configured to use the main Kubelet API."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Worker Nodes"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": 4.4 Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": 4.5 Implement and Manage a Firewall on End -User Devices"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--streaming-connection-idle-timeout argument is not set to 0"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not disable timeouts on streaming connections."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Setting idle timeouts ensures that you are protected against Denial-of-Service attacks
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": inactive connections and running out of ephemeral ports. Note: By default
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": --streaming-connection-idle-timeout is set to 4 hours which might be too high for your environment. Setting this as appropriate would additionally ensure that such streaming connections are timed out after serving legitimate use cases."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--make-iptables-util-chains argument is set to true"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Allow Kubelet to manage iptables."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Kubelets can automatically manage the required changes to iptables based on how you choose your networking options for the pods. It is recommended to let kubelets manage the changes to iptables. This ensures that the iptables configuration remains in sync with pod s networking configuration. Manually configuring iptables with dynamic pod network configuration changes might hamper the communication between pods/containers and to the outside world. You might have iptables rules too restrictive or too open."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Kubelet would manage the iptables on the system and keep it in sync. If you are using any other iptables management solution
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": then there might be some conflicts."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--eventRecordQPS argument is set to 0 or a level which ensures appropriate event capture"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Security relevant information should be captured. The--eventRecordQPS flag on the Kubelet can be used to limit the rate at which events are gathered. Setting this too low could result in relevant events not being logged
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": however the unlimited setting of 0 could result in a denial of service on the kubelet."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "It is important to capture all events and not restrict event creation. Events are an important source of security information and analytics that ensure that your environment is consistently monitored using the event data."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Setting this parameter to 0 could result in a denial of service condition due to excessive events being created. The cluster's event processing and storage systems should be scaled to handle expected event loads."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the--rotate-certificates argument is not set to false"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Enable kubelet client certificate rotation."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "The--rotate-certificates setting causes the kubelet to rotate its client certificates by creating new CSRs as its existing credentials expire. This automated periodic rotation ensures that the there is no downtime due to expired certificates and thus addressing availability in the CIA (Confidentiality
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": Int egrity
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": and Availability) security triad. Note: This recommendation only applies if you let kubelets get their certificates from the API server. In case your kubelet certificates come from an outside authority/tool (e.g. Vault) then you need to implement rotation yourself. Note: This feature also requires the RotateKubeletClientCertificate feature gate to be enabled."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the RotateKubeletServerCertificate argument is set to true"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Enable kubelet server certificate rotation."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "RotateKubeletServerCertificate causes the kubelet to both request a serving certificate after bootstrapping its client credentials and rotate the certificate as its existing credentials expire. This automated periodic rotation ensures that the there are no downtimes due to expired certificates and thus a ddressing availability in the CIA security triad. Note: This recommendation only applies if you let kubelets get their certificates from the API server. In case your kubelet certificates come from an outside authority/tool (e.g. Vault) then you need to take care of rotation yourself."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "None"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Worker Nodes"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that the cluster-admin role is only used where required"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The RBAC role cluster-admin provides wide-ranging powers over the environment and should be used only where and when needed."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Kubernetes provides a set of default roles where RBAC is used. Some of these roles such as cluster-admin provide wide-ranging privileges which should only be applied where absolutely necessary. Roles such as cluster-admin allow super-user access to perform any action on any resource. When used in a ClusterRoleBinding
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": it gives full control over every resource in the cluster and in all namespaces. When used in a RoleBinding
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": it gives full control over every resource in the rolebinding's namespace
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "Care should be taken before removing any clusterrolebindings from the environment to ensure they were not required for operation of the cluster. Specifically
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": modifications should not be made to clusterrolebindings with the system: prefix as they are required for the operation of system components."
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize access to secrets"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The Kubernetes API stores secrets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": which may be service account tokens for the Kubernetes API or credentials used by workloads in the cluster. Access to these secrets should be restricted to the smallest possible group of users to reduce the risk of privilege escalation."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Inappropriate access to secrets stored within the Kubernetes cluster can allow for an attacker to gain additional access to the Kubernetes cluster or external resources whose credentials are stored as secrets."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Care should be taken not to remove access to secrets to system components which require this for their operation"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize wildcard use in Roles and ClusterRoles"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Kubernetes Roles and ClusterRoles provide access to resources based on sets of objects and actions that can be taken on those objects. It is possible to set either of these to be the wildcard '*' which matches all items. Use of wildcards is not optimal from a security perspective as it may allow for inadvertent access to be granted when new resources are added to the Kubernetes API either as CRDs or in later versions of the product."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "The principle of least privilege recommends that users are provided only the access required for their role and nothing more. The use of wildcard rights grants is likely to provide excessive rights to the Kubernetes API."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Policies"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize access to create pods"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The ability to create pods in a namespace can provide a number of opportunities for privilege escalation
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": such as assigning privileged service accounts to these pods or mounting hostPaths with access to sensitive data (unless Pod Security Policies are implemented to restrict this access) As such
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": access to create new pods should be restricted to the smallest possible group of users."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "The ability to create pods in a cluster opens up possibilities for privilege escalation and should be restricted
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "Care should be taken not to remove access to pods to system components which require this for their operation"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that default service accounts are not actively used"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The default service account should not be used to ensure that rights granted to applications can be more easily audited and reviewed."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Kubernetes provides a default service account which is used by cluster workloads where no specific service account is assigned to the pod. Where access to the Kubernetes API from a pod is required
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": a specific service account should be created for that pod
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": and rights granted to that service account. The default service account should be configured such that it does not provide a service account token and does not have any explicit rights assignments."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "All workloads which require access to the Kubernetes API will require an explicit service account to be created."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.7 Manage Default Accounts on Enterprise Assets and Software
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": 5.4 Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that Service Account Tokens are only mounted where necessary"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Service accounts tokens should not be mounted in pods except where the workload running in the pod explicitly needs to communicate with the API server"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Mounting service account tokens inside pods can provide an avenue for privilege escalation attacks where an attacker is able to compromise a single pod in the cluster. Avoiding mounting these tokens removes this attack avenue."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Pods mounted without service account tokens will not be able to communicate with the API server
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": except where the resource is available to unauthenticated principals."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize the admission of privileged containers"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not generally permit containers to be run with the securityContext.privileged flag set to true ."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Privileged containers have access to all Linux Kernel capabilities and devices. A container running with full privileges can do almost everything that the host can do. This flag exists to allow special use-cases
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": like manipulating the network stack and accessing devices. There should be at least one admission control policy defined which does not permit privileged containers. If you need to run privileged containers
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": this should be defined in a separate policy and you should carefully check to ensure that only limited service accounts and users are given permission to use that policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": spec.initContainers[].securityContext.privileged: true and spec.ephemeralContainers[].securityContext.privileged: true will not be permitted. Page 75"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host process ID namespace"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not generally permit containers to be run with the hostPID flag set to true."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "A container running in the host's PID namespace can inspect processes running outside the container. If the container also has access to ptrace capabilities this can be used to escalate privileges outside of the container. There should be at least one admission control policy defined which does not permit containers to share the host PID namespace. If you need to run containers which require hostPID
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": this should be defined in a separate policy and you should carefully check to ensure that only limited service accounts and users are given permission to use that policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Pods defined with spec.hostPID: true will not be permitted unless they are run under a specific policy. Page 78"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host IPC namespace"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not generally permit containers to be run with the hostIPC flag set to true."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "A container running in the host's IPC namespace can use IPC to interact with processes outside the container. There should be at least one admission control policy defined which does not permit containers to share the host IPC namespace. If you need to run containers which require hostIPC
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": this should be defined in a separate policy and you should carefully check to ensure that only limited service accounts and users are given permission to use that policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Pods defined with spec.hostIPC: true will not be permitted unless they are run under a specific policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host network namespace"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not generally permit containers to be run with the hostNetwork flag set to true."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "A container running in the host's network namespace could access the local loopback device
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": and could access network traffic to and from other pods. There should be at least one admission control policy defined which does not permit containers to share the host network namespace. If you need to run containers which require access to the host's network namespaces
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": this should be defined in a separate policy and you should carefully check to ensure that only limited service accounts and users are given permission to use that policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "Pods defined with spec.hostNetwork: true will not be permitted unless they are run under a specific policy. Page 83"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize the admission of containers with allowPrivilegeEscalation"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Do not generally permit containers to be run with the allowPrivilegeEscalation flag set to true . Allowing this right can lead to a process running a container getting more rights than it started with. It's important to note that these rights are still constrained by the overall container sandbox
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": and this setting does not relate to the use of privileged containers."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "A container running with the allowPrivilegeEscalation flag set to true may have processes that can gain more privileges than their parent. There should be at least one admission control policy defined which does not permit containers to allow privilege escalation. The option exists (and is defaulted to true) to permit setuid binaries to run. If you have need to run containers which use setuid binaries or require privilege escalation
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": this should be defined in a separate policy and you should carefully check to ensure that only limited service accounts and users are given permission to use that policy."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "Pods defined with spec.allowPrivilegeEscalation: true will not be permitted unless they are run under a specific policy. Page 86"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure latest CNI version is used"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "There are a variety of CNI plugins available for Kubernetes. If the CNI in use does not support Network Policies it may not be possible to effectively restrict traffic in the cluster."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Kubernetes network policies are enforced by the CNI plugin in use. As such it is important to ensure that the CNI plugin supports both Ingress and Egress network policies."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "None."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Policies"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "16.5 Use Up -to-Date and Trusted Third -Party Software Components"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure that all Namespaces have Network Policies defined"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Use network policies to isolate traffic in your cluster network."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Running different applications on the same Kubernetes cluster creates a risk of one compromised application attacking a neighboring application. Network segmentation is important to ensure that containers can communicate only with those they are supposed to. A network policy is a specification of how selections of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints. Once there is any Network Policy in a namespace selecting a particular pod
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": that pod will reject any connections that are not allowed by any Network Policy. Other pods in the namespace that are not selected by any Network Policy will continue to accept all traffic'"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Once there is any Network Policy in a namespace selecting a particular pod
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": that pod will reject any connections that are not allowed by any Network Policy. Other pods in the namespace that are not selected by any Network Policy will continue to accept all traffic'"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "3.12 Segment Data Processing and Storage Based on Sensitivity
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": 13.4 Perform Traffic Filtering Between Network Segments"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Prefer using secrets as files over secrets as environment variables"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Kubernetes supports mounting secrets as data volumes or as environment variables. Minimize the use of environment variable secrets."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "It is reasonably common for application code to log out its environment (particularly in the event of an error). This will include any secret values passed in as environment variables
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": so secrets can easily be exposed to any user or entity who has access to the logs."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Application code which expects to read secrets in the form of environment variables would need modification"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Consider external secret storage"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Consider the use of an external secrets storage and management system
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": instead of using Kubernetes Secrets directly
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": if you have more complex secret management needs. Ensure the solution requires authentication to access secrets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": has auditing of access to and use of secrets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": and encrypts secrets. Some solutions also make it easier to rotate secrets."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": but care needs to be taken to ensure that access to secrets is carefully limited. Using an external secrets provider can ease the management of access to secrets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": especially where secrests are used across both Kubernetes and non-Kubernetes environments."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Create administrative boundaries between resources using namespaces"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Use namespaces to isolate your Kubernetes objects."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Limiting the scope of user permissions can reduce the impact of mistakes or malicious activities. A Kubernetes namespace allows you to partition created resources into logically named groups. Resources created in one namespace can be hidden from other name spaces. By default
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": each resource created by a user in an Azure AKS cluster runs in a default namespace
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": called default . You can create additional namespaces and attach resources and users to them. You can use Kubernetes Authorization plugins to create pol icies that segregate access to namespace resources between different users."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": "You need to switch between namespaces for administration."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.6 Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Apply Security Context to Your Pods and Containers"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Apply Security Context to Your Pods and Containers"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "A security context defines the operating system security settings (uid
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": gid
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": capabilities
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": etc..) applied to a container. When designing your containers and pods
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": make sure that you configure the security context for your pods
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": an d volumes. A security context is a property defined in the deployment yaml. It controls the security parameters that will be assigned to the pod/container/volume. There are two levels of security context: pod level security context
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_2": and container level sec urity context."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.name": you may have trouble running the pods."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.date": "4.6 Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "The default namespace should not be used"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Kubernetes provides a default namespace
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": where objects are placed if no namespace is specified for them. Placing objects in this namespace makes application of RBAC and other controls more difficult."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Resources in a Kubernetes cluster should be segregated by namespace
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": to allow for security controls to be applied at that level and to make it easier to manage resources."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": 4.6 Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure Image Vulnerability Scanning using Microsoft Defender for Cloud (MDC) image scanning or a third party provider"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Scan images being deployed to Azure (AKS) for vulnerabilities. Vulnerability scanning for images stored in Microsoft Defender for Cloud (MDC). This capability is powered by Microsoft Defender for Endpoint's MDVM
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": a leading provider of information security. When you push an image to Container Registry
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": MDC automatically scans it
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": then checks for known vulnerabilities in packages or dependencies defined in the file. When the scan completes (after about 10 minutes)
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": MDC provides details and a security classification for each vulnerability detected
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": along with guidance on how to remediate issues and protect vulnerable attack surfaces."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": "Vulnerabilities in software packages can be exploited by hackers or malicious users to obtain unauthorized access to local cloud resources."
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": you might occasionally encounter problems. For example
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_2": you might not be able to pull a container image because of an issue with Docker in your local environment. Or
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_3": a network issue might prevent you from connecting to the registry."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.version": "7.5 Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Internal Enterprise Assets
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.date": 7.6 Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Externally -Exposed Enterprise Assets"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize user access to Azure Container Registry (ACR)"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Restrict user access to Azure Container Registry (ACR)
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": limiting interaction with build images to only authorized personnel and service accounts."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Weak access control to Azure Container Registry (ACR) may allow malicious users to replace built images with vulnerable containers."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Care should be taken not to remove access to Azure ACR for accounts that require this for their operation."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize cluster access to read-only for Azure Container Registry (ACR)"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Configure the Cluster Service Account with Storage Object Viewer Role to only allow read-only access to Azure Container Registry (ACR)"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "The Cluster Service Account does not require administrative access to Azure ACR
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": only requiring pull access to containers to deploy onto Azure AKS. Restricting permissions follows the principles of least privilege and prevents credentials from being abused beyond the required role."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "A separate dedicated service account may be required for use by build servers and other robot users pushing or managing container images."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": 7.5 Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Internal Enterprise Assets"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Minimize Container Registries to only those approved"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Use approved container registries."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Allowing unrestricted access to external container registries provides the opportunity for malicious or unapproved containers to be deployed into the cluster. Allowlisting only approved container registries reduces this risk."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "All container images to be deployed to the cluster must be hosted within an approved container image registry."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Managed services"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Prefer using dedicated AKS Service Accounts"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Kubernetes workloads should not use cluster node service accounts to authenticate to Azure AKS APIs. Each Kubernetes workload that needs to authenticate to other Azure Web Services using IAM should be provisioned with a dedicated Service account."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Manual approaches for authenticating Kubernetes workloads running on Azure AKS against Azure APIs are: storing service account keys as a Kubernetes secret (which introduces manual key rotation and potential for key compromise); or use of the underlying nod es' IAM Service account
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": which violates the principle of least privilege on a multi-tenanted node
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": when one pod needs to have access to a service
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": but every other pod on the node that uses the Service account does not."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": "5.4 Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure Kubernetes Secrets are encrypted"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Encryption at Rest is a common security requirement. In Azure
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": organizations can encrypt data at rest without the risk or cost of a custom key management solution. Organizations have the option of letting Azure completely manage Encryption at Rest. Additio nally
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": organizations have various options to closely manage encryption or encryption keys."

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Restrict Access to the Control Plane Endpoint"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Enable Endpoint Private Access to restrict access to the cluster's control plane to only an allowlist of authorized IPs."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Authorized networks are a way of specifying a restricted range of IP addresses that are permitted to access your cluster's control plane. Kubernetes Engine uses both Transport Layer Security (TLS) and authentication to provide secure access to your cluster 's control plane from the public internet. This provides you the flexibility to administer your cluster from anywhere; however
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": you might want to further restrict access to a set of IP addresses that you control. You can set this restriction by specifying an authorized network. Restricting access to an authorized network can provide additional security benefits for your container cluster
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": including: - Better protection from outsider attacks: Authorized networks provide an additional layer of security by limiting external access to a specific set of addresses you designate
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": such as those that originate from your premises. This helps protect access to you r cluster in the case of a vulnerability in the cluster's authentication or authorization mechanism. - Better protection from insider attacks: Authorized networks help protect your cluster from accidental leaks of master certificates from your company's premises. Leaked certificates used from outside Azure virtual machines and outside the authorized IP rang es (for example
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": from addresses outside your company) are still denied access."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": be careful to ensure all desired networks are on the allowlist (whitelist) to prevent inadvertently blocking external access to your cluster's control plane. Limitations IP authorized ranges can't be applied to the private api server endpoint
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": they only apply to the public API server Availability Zones are currently supported for certain regions. Azure Private Link service limitations apply to private clusters. No support for Azure DevOps Microsoft-hosted Agents with private clusters. Consider to use Self-hosted Agents. For customers that need to enable Azure Container Registry to work with private AKS
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_2": the Container Registry virtual network must be peered with the agent cluster virtual network. Page 124"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure clusters are created with Private Endpoint Enabled and Public Access Disabled"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Disable access to the Kubernetes API from outside the node network if it is not required."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "In a private cluster
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": the master node has two endpoints
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": a private and public endpoint. The private endpoint is the internal IP address of the master
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.v8": behind an internal load balancer in the master's wirtual network. Nodes communicate with the master using the private endpoint. The public endpoint enables the Kubernetes API to be accessed from outside the master's virtual network. Although Kubernetes API requires an authorized token to perform sensitive actions
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": a vulnerability could potentially expose the Kubernetes publically with unrestricted access. Additionally
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": an attacker may be able to identify the current cluster and Kubern etes API version and determine whether it is vulnerable to an attack. Unless required
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": disabling public endpoint will help prevent such threats
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": and require the attacker to be on the master's virtual network to perform any attack on the Kubernetes API."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.name": "4.4 Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure clusters are created with Private Nodes"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Disable public IP addresses for cluster nodes
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": so that they only have private IP addresses. Private Nodes are nodes with no public IP addresses."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Disabling public IP addresses on cluster nodes restricts access to only internal networks
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": forcing attackers to obtain local network access before attempting to compromise the underlying Kubernetes hosts."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": the cluster has to also be configured with a private master IP range and IP Aliasing enabled. Private Nodes do not have outbound access to the public internet. If you want to provide outbound Internet access for your private nodes
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": you can use Cloud NAT or you can manage your own NAT gateway."
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": "4.4 Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Ensure Network Policy is Enabled and set as appropriate"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "When you run modern
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": microservices-based applications in Kubernetes
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": you often want to control which components can communicate with each other. The principle of least privilege should be applied to how traffic can flow between pods in an Azure Kubernetes Service ( AKS) cluster. Let's say you likely want to block traffic directly to back-end applications. The Network Policy feature in Kubernetes lets you define rules for ingress and egress traffic between pods in a cluster."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "All pods in an AKS cluster can send and receive traffic without limitations
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": you can define rules that control the flow of traffic. Back-end applications are often only exposed to required front-end services
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig3": database components are only accessible to the application tiers that connect to them. Network Policy is a Kubernetes specification that defines access policies for communication between Pods. Using Network Policies
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": you define an ordered set of rules to send and receive traffic and apply them to a collection of pods that match one or more l abel selectors. These network policy rules are defined as YAML manifests. Network policies can be included as part of a wider manifest that also creates a deployment or service."
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_2": "Network Policy requires the Network Policy add-on. This add-on is included automatically when a cluster with Network Policy is created
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.name": needs to be added prior to enabling Network Policy. Enabling/Disabling Network Policy causes a rolling update of all cluster nodes
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.version": similar to performing a cluster upgrade. This operation is long-running and will block other operations on the cluster (including delete) until it has run to completion. If Network Policy is used
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.document.date": a cluster must have at least 2 nodes of type n1-standard-1 or higher. The recommended minimum size cluster to run Network Policy enforcement is 3 n1-standard-1 instances. Enabling Network Policy enforcement consumes additional resources in nodes. Specifically
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.version": it increases the memory footprint of the kube-system process by approximately 128MB
"ssphp.metadata.last_updated_by": and requires approximately 300 millicores of CPU. Page 131"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Encrypt traffic to HTTPS load balancers with TLS certificates"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Encrypt traffic to HTTPS load balancers using TLS certificates."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": "Encrypting traffic between users and your Kubernetes workload is fundamental to protecting data sent over the web."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": "Managed services"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Manage Kubernetes RBAC users with Azure AD"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) can be configured to use Azure Active Directory (AD) for user authentication. In this configuration
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": you sign in to an AKS cluster using an Azure AD authentication token. You can also configure Kubernetes role-based access control (Kubernetes RBAC) to limit access to cluster resources based a user's identity or group membership."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": "Kubernetes RBAC and AKS help you secure your cluster access and provide only the minimum required permissions to developers and operators."
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": 6.8 Define and Maintain Role -Based Access Control"

"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.title": "Use Azure RBAC for Kubernetes Authorization"
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.descriptio: "The ability to manage RBAC for Kubernetes resources from Azure gives you the choice to manage RBAC for the cluster resources either using Azure or native Kubernetes mechanisms. When enabled
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.rationale": Azure AD principals will be validated exclusively by Azure RBAC while regular Kubernetes users and service accounts are exclusively validated by Kubernetes RBAC. Azure role-based access control (RBAC) is an authorization system built on Azure Resource Manager that provides fine-grained access management of Azure resources. With Azure RBAC
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.impact": you create a role definition that outlines the permissions to be applied. You then assign a user or group this role definition via a role assignment for a particular scope. The scope can be an individual resource
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.control.group": a resource group
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig1": "Today you can already leverage integrated authentication between Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) and AKS. When enabled
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.controls.ig2": this integration allows customers to use Azure AD users
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_1": or service principals as subjects in Kubernetes RBAC. This feature fr ees you from having to separately manage user identities and credentials for Kubernetes. However
"ssphp.use_case.framework.ig_2": you still have to set up and manage Azure RBAC and Kubernetes RBAC separately. Azure RBAC for Kubernetes Authorization is an approach that allows for the unif ied management and access control across Azure Resources
"ssphp.cis_benchmark.version": "4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
